coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of ZIF-8 incorporated electrospun PAN/PEI nanofibrous composite membrane for efficient Cr(VI) adsorption from water

Abdel-Mohsen, A.M.
Zhang, Qi-Jun
Younas, Mohammad
Zhong, Lu-Bin
Yang, Jia-Cheng E.
Zheng, Yu-Ming
coredata.dc:description: Hexavalent chromium Cr(VI) is one of the most toxic heavy metal ions. Therefore, the removal of this contaminant from wastewater is of particular importance. Herein, a novel zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanoparticles based electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN)/polyethylenimine (PEI) nanofibrous composite membranes (NCMs) were prepared and characterized by SEM, XRD, FTIR, TGA and other characterization techniques. The NCMs were tested for the adsorption of Cr(VI) from water. Results showed that the inclusion of PEI tailored the surface of the NCM to be superhydrophilic. The prepared electrospun NCM showed a high adsorption capacity for Cr(VI) (up to 403.5 mg·g−1) under ZIF-8 concentration of 5 wt%. More importantly, introducing ZIF-8 up to 5 % did not only increase the adsorption capacity but also enhanced the thermal stability, mechanical strength, and structure of the NCM. The experimental analysis of co-existing ions and the reusability of up to ten cycles showed that the optimized PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM exhibited good selectivity and excellent stability for wastewater treatment. The adsorption kinetics followed the pseudo-second-order model and the adsorption isotherm could be fitted well by the Langmuir model. Thermodynamics revealed that the adsorption process was spontaneous and endothermic. The adsorption mechanism was found to be mainly electrostatic attraction and reduction. This study demonstrated the potential of ZIF-8-incorporated PAN/PEI NCMs for the removal of Cr(VI) from water.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Hexavalent chromium Cr(VI) is one of the most toxic heavy metal ions. Therefore, the removal of this contaminant from wastewater is of particular importance. Herein, a novel zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanoparticles based electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN)/polyethylenimine (PEI) nanofibrous composite membranes (NCMs) were prepared and characterized by SEM, XRD, FTIR, TGA and other characterization techniques. The NCMs were tested for the adsorption of Cr(VI) from water. Results showed that the inclusion of PEI tailored the surface of the NCM to be superhydrophilic. The prepared electrospun NCM showed a high adsorption capacity for Cr(VI) (up to 403.5 mg·g−1) under ZIF-8 concentration of 5 wt%. More importantly, introducing ZIF-8 up to 5 % did not only increase the adsorption capacity but also enhanced the thermal stability, mechanical strength, and structure of the NCM. The experimental analysis of co-existing ions and the reusability of up to ten cycles showed that the optimized PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM exhibited good selectivity and excellent stability for wastewater treatment. The adsorption kinetics followed the pseudo-second-order model and the adsorption isotherm could be fitted well by the Langmuir model. Thermodynamics revealed that the adsorption process was spontaneous and endothermic. The adsorption mechanism was found to be mainly electrostatic attraction and reduction. This study demonstrated the potential of ZIF-8-incorporated PAN/PEI NCMs for the removal of Cr(VI) from water.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: With the rapid expansion of industries worldwide and the development of new technologies, the amount of wastewater produced has increased dramatically. This wastewater is improperly discharged, resulting in considerable pollution of heavy metal ions [1,2]. Chromium (Cr) is a well-known carcinogen contaminant released from electroplating, metal finishing, textiles, coating, leather tanning, and other chemical industries. Typically, Cr is found in two states in water, hexavalent Cr(VI) and trivalent Cr(III). Cr(VI) is more toxic, water-soluble, and mutagenic to living organisms as compared to Cr(III). It is indispensable to develop materials with high removal capacity, selectivity, and environmentally friendly regeneration abilities [3].

Recently, considerable efforts have been put into developing effective methods and materials for removing heavy metals, including Cr(VI), from aqueous streams. These methods include reductive precipitation [4], photocatalytic reduction [5], membrane separation [6], ion exchange [7], and adsorption coupled reduction remediation [8]. Among these methods, adsorption with reduction is by far the most common method for Cr(VI) removal from wastewater due to its ease of operation and simple design [9]. The existing adsorption techniques demerits are loss of removal efficiency, detachment of active species on adsorbents, use of toxic chemicals and their leaching in aqueous media, and less regenerative cycles of adsorbent. Nevertheless, a trade-off exists between adsorption capacity and their long-term use for the removal of adsorbate from aqueous media. Apart from them, most of the adsorbents, though achieve better adsorption efficiency, their operating parameters like pH, adsorbent dosage and excessive regeneration cycles make them difficult in practical applications. Thus, a facile method to develop environmentally friendly and durable adsorbents is necessary from efficient materials.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new kind of porous materials with a large specific surface area constructed by coordinating interactions between metal ions or ion clusters and organic linkers that have led to widespread interest as potential adsorbents. Among the different MOFs, the zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) is prepared by a simple synthesis route from inexpensive materials and characterized by a high specific surface area with abundant surface charges [10]. ZIF-8 has been found to be environmentally friendly, thermally/chemically stable, and with tunable morphology, applied in different wastewater treatments, including removal of antibiotics [11], oil emulsion [12], dyes [13], organic pollutants [14], heavy metal ions [15], and radioactive metal ions [16]. However, ZIF-8 has a considerable void space, a hydrophilic surface, and only a few unsaturated metal centers, leading to a decreased adsorption affinity [17,18]. Moreover, the nanometer size range of ZIF-8 in a powdery form can lead to handling issues during the adsorption in purification systems, causing difficulties in the adsorbent’s reclamation. Therefore, incorporating ZIF-8 with a highly hydrophilic polymer into various substrates is a viable option for creating shapeable and high-efficiency adsorbent materials [19].

Polyethylenimine (PEI) is a cationic polyelectrolyte with abundant primary, secondary, and tertiary amine groups on its macromolecular chain. The amines are considered potential functional groups for sequestering heavy metal ions, including Cr(VI), through electrostatic interaction and coordination [20,21]. Moreover, they can also reduce Cr(VI) to harmless Cr(III). However, PEI is a highly water-soluble polymer that needs to be immobilized on other ideal substrates to be stable and usable in practical applications [22]. Instead, grafting of PEI with other materials could demonstrate a high adsorption capacity for different heavy metals. For instance, Zhao et al. grafted branched PEI on electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN) fibers, where the amine groups showed an excellent adsorption capacity with a maximum capacity of 637.46 mg·g−1 towards Cr(VI) under certain operating parameters [23]. More recently, Zhang et al. also functionalized porous cellulose nanofibers/PEI composite aerogel for methyl orange (MO) removal with the help of epichlorohydrin (ECH) as a crosslinker. The composite showed a high adsorption capacity for the MO [24]. However, despite the high values of adsorption capacity for the different adsorbates, synthetic polymeric composites (adsorbents) possess low mechanical, thermal, and chemical properties which is the major drawback of using them in harsh practical applications. Therefore, it is of great interest to synthesize an efficient, capable to work in harsh conditions and regeneratable with long and stable performance adsorbent. In the current work, novel electrospun nanofibrous composite membranes (NCMs) were developed with the incorporation of ZIF-8 nanoparticles into a polymeric substrate and grafted with a cationic polyelectrolyte for the first time. As expected, the electrospinning technique not only offers a feasible approach to address the mentioned issues but produced nanofibers (NFs) inheriting the benefits of ZIF-8 and PEI with improved adsorbents structure and characteristics. The PAN was chosen as a flexible polymer carrier due to its good electrospinnability and high thermal and chemical characteristics [25].

Inspired by the unique features of electrospinning, ZIF-8, and PEI, in this study, we fabricated PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 composite NFs inheriting the merits of ZIF-8 and PEI without using a crosslinker or special treatment through a simple electrospinning method. The NFs were used for the removal of Cr(VI) from wastewater and demonstrated excellent efficiency. Different techniques were used to characterize the fabricated NFs adsorbents, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), water contact angle (WCA), thermogravimetric analysis curve (TGA), and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). The influence of different parameters, including pH, MOF content, and contact time was investigated. Kinetics, isotherm, thermodynamics, adsorption selectivity, and regeneration studies were also presented in detail. The regeneration cycles study of the developed adsorbent and its performance in co-existing cations and anions in aqueous media were also investigated.

Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, Mw = 90,000) was purchased from Kunshan Hong Yu Plastic Co., Ltd (Suzhou, China). Polyethyleneimine (PEI, Mw = 70000, 50% aqueous solution) was purchased from Aladdin. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (99%) was purchased from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 97%) and 2-methylimidazole (98%) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biomedical Co., Ltd. Hydrochloric acid (HCl, AR, 36%–38%), potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, C 99.5%), ethanol absolute (EtOH, AR, C 99.7%), methanol (MeOH, AR, C 99.5%) and all inorganic salts were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). All water used in this work was ultra-pure (18.2 MΩ·cm) prepared by a purification system unless otherwise stated.

0.730 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 40 mL methanol and sonicated for 10 min to form solution A. Similarly, 3.285 g of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in 40 mL methanol and sonicated for 10 min to form solution B. The two solutions were then mixed and stirred vigorously for 3 h at 25 ± 2 °C. Subsequently, the turbid mixture was separated by centrifugation (10000 rpm) yielding white precipitates that were washed with methanol three times and once with ethanol before drying at 60 °C under vacuum.

The spinning solution of PAN/PEI was optimized by mixing different amounts of PEI (30, 40, and 50 wt%) and 10 wt% PAN in DMF. First, 10 wt% PAN spinning solution was dissolved in DMF and agitated at 60 °C for 6 h. In parallel, different concentrations of ZIF-8 (0–10 wt%) were dissolved into DMF and sonicated for 10 min followed by stirring for 1 h at 60 °C. PEI (30, 40, 50 wt%) was added into DMF with a certain amount of ZIF-8 and stirred at 60 °C for an additional 5 h. PAN solution was then mixed with PEI-ZIF-8 solution (2:1 w/w) at 25 ± 2 °C for 3 h. The mixed solution was used for electrospinning with the following conditions: a voltage of 17 kV, a flow rate of 0.0012 mL·s−1, and a needle tip to collector distance of 13 cm.

The structural morphology of the synthesized ZIF-8 and electrospun PEI-PAN@ZIF-8 NCMs was obtained by a Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) operated at 5 kV after being sputter-coated with platinum by an EMS 150T ES turbo pumped sputter coater (Pennsylvania) for better contrast. An energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX, Apollo XL, EDAX) was used to obtain the elemental map of the samples. Fourier-transform infrared FTIR spectroscopy for identifying functional groups was obtained using a Nicolet iS10 spectrometer with a transmission mode and a scan range of 400–4000 cm−1. XRD patterns were used to identify the structure of the synthesized ZIF-8 via a PANalytical X’ Pert PRO (Almelo, Netherlands) with a diffraction range of 20-80° and scanning speed of 0.03° (2θ) s−1. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area (BET-SSA) analysis was performed by a surface area analyzer (Micrometrics, ASAP 2020). The surface water contact angles (WCAs) of the as produced samples of PAN, PAN/PEI (10/30 % w/w), and PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (10/30@5 % w/w) were examined via the sessile drop method by a contact angle analyzer (DSA 100, KRUSS, Germany). Thermal stabilities of the ZIF-8 and the NFs adsorbents were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements, which were taken from 35 to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 and a nitrogen gas flow rate of 60 mL·min−1 using a TG209F3 Tarsus (NETZSCH, Germany) instrument. The mechanical properties of the obtained NFs adsorbents (NCMs) were tested by an AGS-X tensile tester (Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto, Japan) at a crosshead speed of 10 mm·min−1. A streaming potential analyzer (SurPASS 3, Anton Paar, Austria) with an automated titrating assembly was used to measure the zeta potential of the NFs surface in a KCl electrolyte solution (1 mM). XPS spectra were obtained with a PHI Quantum-2000 electron spectrometer (Ulvac-Phi, Japan). ICP-OES (Optima 7000DV) was used to quantify the final concentration of total Cr(VI) concentration.

Batch equilibrium adsorption experiments were carried out in a thermostat shaker operating at (25 °C and 150 rpm). The inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) technique was used to determine the residual concentration of Cr(VI) after being filtered with a 0.45 μm syringe filter. The adsorption capacity Qe (mg·g−1) is calculated according to the following equation (1):

V denotes the volume (L) of the testing solution, and m is the weight (g) of the adsorbent. Each experiment was carried out in triplicate and the findings were calculated as averages to ensure reliability.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of ZIF-8 loading in adsorbent and pH of aqueous solution
ce:section.ce:para: The effects of ZIF-8 loading (0–10%) in PAN/PEI NCM and of the initial pH of aqueous solution over a pH range of 2.0–7.0 on the removal efficiency of Cr(VI) were investigated . Briefly, 10 ± 0.1 mg of the adsorbent was introduced to a 50 mL solution with initial Cr(VI) concentrations of 50 and 100 mg·L−1 for pH and ZIF-8 loading effect studies, respectively. The initial pH values were adjusted using dropwise addition of 0.1 M aqueous solution of NaOH or HCl.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of contact time and adsorption kinetics models
ce:section.ce:para: Kinetics experiments were carried out by adding 10 ± 0.1 mg of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 into a 50 mL aqueous solution of 50 mg·L−1 Cr(VI). The samples were taken at appropriate time intervals (0–960 min) and analyzed for Cr(VI) concentration by ICP-OES.

Three kinetics models, namely pseudo-first-order (PFO), pseudo-second-order (PSO), and intra-particle diffusion (IPD) models, were implemented to fit the experimental data. The PFO and PSO kinetic models can be expressed by the following equations, respectively:

Where Kd (mL·g−1) is the distribution coefficient of Cr(VI), T (K) is the experimental temperature, and R (8.314 J·mol−1·K−1) is the ideal gas constant.

Cr(VI) adsorption onto the optimized PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM in the presence of competitive ions (calcium, sodium, potassium, nitrate, chloride, and sulfate) was investigated. The effect of each competitive ion was monitored at concentrations of 100 and 200 mg·L−1 at 25 ± 2 0C. PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (10 mg) was mixed with Cr(VI) (20 mg·L−1, 20 mL) aqueous solution.

Adsorption-desorption cyclic experiments were conducted by adding 10 ± 0.1 mg NF adsorbent (NCM) in 20 mL of 20 mg·L−1 Cr(VI) solution for 16 h. The Cr(VI) loaded NCM was regenerated with 0.05 M NaOH for 1 h at 25 ± 2 0C, then taken out for proper washing with ultrapure water to neutral pH, then used for the next adsorption test. The adsorption/desorption cycle experiments were carried out 10 times.

The XRD patterns of the as-synthesized ZIF-8, PAN/PEI, and PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (5%) electrospun NFs composites are shown in Fig. 1
a. The ZIF-8 patterns correspond to a sodalite structure with high purity and crystallinity. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 7.4°, 10.5°, 12.9°, 14.9°, 16.7°, 18.3°, 22.3°, 24.6°, 26.9°, and 29.9° corresponding to (0 1 1), (0 0 2), (1 1 2), (0 2 2), (0 1 3), (2 2 2), (1 1 4), (2 3 3), (1 3 4), and (0 4 4) diffraction planes, respectively, indicating the crystalline structure of ZIF-8 MOFs. The most notable reflections were in line with earlier reports [26,27]. It is demonstrated that adding a small amount of ZIF-8 to the PAN/PEI NFs composites drastically decreased the intensity of the peaks. For example, a few peaks were preserved within the angle range of 10-15°. This could be attributed to the presence of the small amount of ZIF-8 loading in the NFs composite and the high amorphous nature of PEI, which obscured the XRD patterns [28]. The SEM image of the ZIF-8 MOF is illustrated in Fig. 1 b, which shows uniform pseudo-cubic-like and hexagonal nanoparticles. The specific surface area and the average pore size of the ZIF-8 nanoparticles determined through BET were found to be 1219.3 m2·g−1 and 3.5 nm, respectively.

The FTIR spectra of ZIF-8 MOF, PAN, and PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (5%) are presented in Fig. 2 . For ZIF-8, the characteristic peak at 421 cm−1 belongs to the vibration stretching of Zn–N, where the 2-methylimidazole linker serves as a bonding connection between zinc (Zn) and nitrogen (N) atoms [29]. The two absorption bands at 3136 and 2929 cm−1 correspond to C-H stretching from the aromatic ring and the aliphatic chain in the imidazole (C3N2H4) units, while the peaks allocated at 1585, 1147, and 995 cm−1 are assigned to the vibrations of C = N and C-N. The different allocated peaks from 1350 to 1500 cm−1 are associated with the vibration of the entire ring, while the wide band around 3435 cm−1 is assigned to stretching vibrations by the water (H2O) and hydroxyl (–OH) groups [27]. So far, FTIR of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 is concerned, there are some new arising bands compared with pristine PAN. The wide band centered at 3440 cm−1 is assigned to amino (–NH2) and imino (-C = N) groups. Additionally, two new peaks at 1650 and 1560 cm−1 appeared, which are attributed to the amide (–CO-NH) and amine (–NH) groups, respectively, indicating the crosslinking between PEI and PAN. The intensities of the two absorption peaks of acrylonitrile and methyl acrylate at 2245 and 1741 cm−1, respectively, decreased significantly with the introduction of PEI, which also confirms the successful amination of PAN [30].

The influence of PEI concentration on the synthesis of NFs was examined during the electrospinning. Highly concentrated PEI (50 wt%) formed a gelatinous spinning solution after mixing with PAN and was hardly spun to produce NFs ( Fig. S1
a). A lower concentration of PEI (40 wt%) produced good NFs with some beads ( Fig. S1
b). Further decrease in PEI concentration to 30 wt% led to smooth free-beaded PAN/PEI NFs with tubular-like shapes and large diameters (Fig. 3 a). However, by introducing ZIF-8 (3–5%) into the PAN/PEI electrospinning solution as observed in Fig. 3b, c, the irregular longitudinal and transverse interlaced fibers were transformed in some way to a raspberry shape with better uniformity and smaller diameters than the PAN/PEI NFs alone. Such transformation in the NFs' surface structure could be beneficial for trapping Cr(VI). Nevertheless, for PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (10%), as observed in Fig. 3 d, MOF (ZIF-8) nanoparticles were agglomerated on the fibers, which could badly affect the adsorption removal efficiency of Cr(VI) from aqueous streams. The dispersion of ZIF-8 into both the inner pores and the surface of the NFs could explain this behavior. Fig. S2 also confirms the formation of NCM through the EDS mapping images of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 for C, N, O, and Zn. Therefore, PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (10/30@5 % w/w) was selected for further experiments.

To demonstrate the surface hydrophilicity of the fabricated adsorbents, we investigated the WCA of pristine PAN (10 wt%), PAN/PEI (10/30 % w/w), and PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (10/30@5 % w/w) (Fig. 4
a-c). PAN exhibited a hydrophobic surface with a contact angle of 114.06° ± 3.5. The surface showed complete wettability after introducing PEI, proving that the surface was altered to a superhydrophilic surface. This is due to the addition of hydrophilic groups of amines on PEI chains. Similar results have been documented when blending PEI with different polymers [31,32]. With further addition of 5 % ZIF-8, the WCA did not change and exhibited a superhydrophilic property.

Thermal stability is a critical parameter for evaluating whether a material is easily decomposable at high temperatures. In this study, the thermal stability of the prepared ZIF-8 and NFs adsorbents was investigated under an inert environment. As depicted in Fig. 5
a, ZIF-8 nanoparticles showed excellent thermal stability with a very stable structure within a wide range of temperatures, attributed to the existence of coordination bonds. The nanoparticles exhibited a slight weight loss of about 5% up to 500 °C, which might be due to the evaporation of water, solvent, and the carbonization of organic ligand molecules in ZIF-8. In contrast, the first steep weight loss occurred rapidly when the temperature crossed 600 °C. This sudden weight loss is attributed to the degradation of organic linkers [33].

The membrane degradation process is well known to be segmented into three evident weight-loss phases. The first stage is assigned due to the guest molecules and solvent evaporation. The second and third stages are attributed to the pyrolysis of functional groups in the polymer and degradation of the polymer backbone [34]. In the case of PAN/PEI NFs adsorbent, the first weight loss stage was observed up to 113 °C with a weight loss of ∼17 %, attributed to the removal of the high water content (PEI, Mw = 70.000, 50% H2O). The second stage began at ∼269 to ∼400 °C with a noticeable weight loss linked to the pyrolytic decomposition of the polymers functional groups [35,36]. The subsequent stage was attributed to the arbitrary degradation of the carbon skeleton in the NFs adsorbent until the fibers slowed down and the weight of the fibers started to stabilize. The degradation of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 (5%) and relatively less weight loss appeared at a comparatively higher temperature than the PAN/PEI NFs, which could be attributed to the superior thermal stability of ZIF-8.

Stress–strain curves were also plotted to characterize the mechanical properties of the fabricated NFs (Fig. 5 b-c). The tensile strength of pristine PAN NFs is 3.66 ± 0.60 MPa and the elongation at break is 31.40 ± 3.28%. After blending PAN with PEI, a slight increase in the tensile strength could be seen as 3.75 ± 0.51 MPa and the elongation at break decreased to 19.36 ± 2.59%. Incorporating the ZIF-8 in the NFs composite increased the tensile strength to 4.35 ± 0.30 MPa and reduced the elongation at break to 17.38 ± 2.04%. The enhancement in the mechanical property could be attributed to the high stability of the loaded ZIF-8 and the better structure uniformity that ZIF-8 could provide. Therefore, the demonstrated good mechanical properties ensure the suitability of the NFs adsorbent for practical applications of heavy metal ions adsorption.

The solution pH exerts a great influence on Cr(VI) adsorption due to its anionic nature [37]. To better understand how the surface charge of the adsorbent affects the adsorption process, the point of zero charge pH (pHpzc) of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 was investigated by plotting zeta potential versus pH. As shown in Fig. 6
a, the results indicate that pHpzc is 8.84, illustrating that the surface of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 is positively charged at solution pH < pHpzc and negatively charged at solution pH greater than 8.84, which is higher than the pHpzc of pristine PAN (3.14, not shown in Fig. 6 a) and PAN/PEI (8.30) indicating that ZIF-8 and PEI have high electric points and positively charged under alkaline conditions. Thus, the addition of ZIF-8 increased the surface charge from pHpzc of 8.30 to 8.84 [38].

Fig. 6 b illustrates the effect of the initial solution pH on adsorption, which shows that the decrease in pH from 7 to 3 enhanced the adsorption capacity, maintaining the highest capacity at pH 3, attributed to the protonation of amine (–NH) and hydroxyl (–OH) functional groups of the NFs. A similar phenomenon could also be found in the literature [39,40]. From the distribution of K2Cr2O7 in water at different pH values (Fig. 6 c), it is known that the predominant forms of Cr(VI) in aqueous solution within pH 2–6 are Cr2O7 2− and HCrO4 −. As a result, electrostatic interaction could primarily be the driving factor behind the adsorption of Cr(VI) anions in the positively charged –NH and –OH groups of the NFs. However, it can be noticed that the adsorption capacity at pH 3 is higher than that at pH 2 which shows good agreement with the Pourbaix diagram where it is found that Cr2O7 2− and HCrO4 − are the prevalent species of Cr(VI) at pH 3 [41]. Another reason could be that in an acidic pH range of 0 to 2.5, the oxidation of the chromate solution becomes stronger and it readily participates in redox interactions with other substances. Thus, a fraction of Cr(VI) is reduced to the less toxic Cr(III) (also confirmed by XPS), which blocks the adsorption sites of the protonated groups [23].

The effect of ZIF-8 loading on PAN/PEI NFs on Cr(VI) adsorption from aqueous solution under 100 mg·L−1 initial concentration and pH 3 is illustrated in Fig. 6 d. The dosage of NFs adsorbent was taken as 0.2 g·L−1. As shown, by incorporating ZIF-8 up to 5 wt% in the NFs adsorbent, the adsorption capacity increased significantly from 154.55 to 238.20 mg·g−1. When the content of ZIF-8 increased to 10 wt% in the NCM, a lower adsorption capacity was observed, which could be attributed to the aggregation of some ZIF-8 particles as confirmed in the SEM (Fig. 3 d) resulting in a decrease in the specific surface area, a decrease in the adsorption inside the NFs core pores, and a reduction in the active sites available for metal ion adsorption.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of contact time and adsorption kinetics model
ce:section.ce:para:
The adsorption process is time-dependent, hence determining the equilibrium adsorption time is crucial. Fig. 7
a shows the effect of contact time on the Cr(VI) uptake. Evidently, the adsorbent showed rapid adsorption in the first 90 min due to vacant adsorption sites followed by slow adsorption until they reached equilibrium in 960 min.

The adsorbate’s uptake rate at the solid-solution interface can be described by adsorption kinetics, which provides vital information regarding reaction routes and processes. Three commonly used kinetics models, namely PFO, PSO, and IPD kinetics models, were implemented to fit the experimental data by nonlinear fitting. From Fig. 7 b and judging by the correlation coefficients R2, the experimental data were well fitted with the PSO kinetics model compared with the other models, indicating chemisorption occurred during the uptake of Cr(VI) from the aqueous solution. Furthermore, the adsorption capacity (Qe.cal = 160.86 mg·g−1), calculated from the PSO kinetics model, is almost identical to the experimentally obtained value (Qe.exp = 161.55 mg·g−1).

The IPD kinetics model (Fig. 7 c) divides the Cr(VI) adsorption into three stages, implying that multiple processes influenced the adsorption process. The steepness of the first linear segment indicated a rapid adsorption stage. The second stage suggested the IPD, while the third stage was deemed the final equilibrium due to the lack of adsorption sites. The experimental results and kinetics model data revealed that the adsorption processes are affected by both external and intra-particle diffusion. This also implies that intraparticle diffusion is not the sole rate-limiting factor in the adsorption process. The determination coefficients are tabulated in Table 1 .

The adsorption isotherms depict the equilibrium of the adsorbate between the liquid phase (Ce) and the solid phase (Qe) for different concentrations at a known temperature and pH of the solution [42]. Three commonly used different models, namely Langmuir, Freundlich, and Temkin, were utilized to fit the adsorption equilibrium data. The Langmuir model implies that adsorption occurs on the surface of the adsorbent and is often used to describe monolayer adsorption. The Freundlich isotherm model describes multilayer adsorption on a heterogeneous adsorbent surface, revealing a nonuniform energy distribution. The Temkin isotherm model assumes that the adsorption heat of all molecules drops linearly as the adsorbent surface is covered by adsorbent-adsorbate interactions and that adsorption is distinguished by a uniform distribution of binding energies.

Fig. 8
a shows the fitted experimental data with the isotherm models, and Table 2 summarizes their corresponding parameters as described in eqs. (5–7). Among them, the Langmuir model showed the highest value of the correlation coefficient (R2 = 0.998), revealing that the adsorption process is monolayer and more suitable for homogeneous adsorption than heterogeneous with the theoretical maximum adsorption capacity (Qm, cal) of 403.5 mg·g−1, which is quite similar to the Qm.exp obtained from the experimental data (375.0 mg·g−1). Furthermore, the relatively high R2 of the Temkin model (R2 = 0.996) revealed a strong electrostatic interaction between Cr(VI) and PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 [43]. The comparison of the Qm of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 with other adsorbents is tabulated in Table 3 . Compared with other adsorbents, the fabricated PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 has an outstanding removal/adsorption capability toward Cr(VI) with a high adsorption capacity (Qm).

Thermodynamic study is carried out mainly to investigate the thermal characteristics of materials from an energy conversion point of view. Three different temperatures were utilized for the adsorption process to explore three main thermodynamic parameters, Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°), standard enthalpy change (ΔH°), and standard entropy change (ΔS°). From the intercept and slope of the plot of ln Kd versus 1/T (Fig. 8 b), the increase in the adsorption capacity with an increase in temperature of the aqueous solution and the obtained positive ΔH° indicate an endothermic nature of the adsorption process. The negative ΔG° confirms the spontaneity of the adsorption process, and the small value indicates that the adsorption forces were strong. Furthermore, the positive value of ΔS° suggests an increase in randomness at the solid-solution interface during the adsorption process. The data of ΔG°, ΔH°, and ΔS° are listed in Table 4

Generally, different anions and cations can be found in natural and contaminated water, and these co-existing ions could also affect the efficiency of Cr(VI) adsorption via competitive binding [56]. Therefore, the effect of co-existing ions in solution, including various anions like chloride (Cl−), sulfate (SO4 2−), nitrate (NO3 −), and different cations like calcium (Ca2+), sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), on the adsorption of Cr(VI) ions on PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM was examined. As shown in Fig. 9 , when the initial concentration of the co-existing anions and cations was 100 mg·L−1, the adsorption capacity was slightly affected. However, when the initial concentration increased to 200 mg·L−1, the effect can be seen obviously with an approximately 15% decrease in the adsorption capacity for all ions except for SO4 2− which showed about 30 % decrease in the adsorption capacity. This clearly demonstrates the competitive suppression of Cr(VI) adsorption [57].

In an effort to gain a better understanding of the Cr(VI) adsorption mechanism, XPS measurements of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 before and after Cr(VI) adsorption were performed. Fig. 10
a shows the wide-scan XPS spectra of the unused and exhausted NFs adsorbent with Cr(VI). After the adsorption of Cr(VI) onto the PAN/PEI@ZIF-8, two new peaks within the range of 570–590 eV were observed in the wide-scan spectra, which were attributed to the characteristic peaks of Cr 2p, indicating that Cr(VI) was successfully adsorbed onto the adsorbent. The high-resolution Cr 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 10 b) showed that there were two peaks with binding energies of 575 eV and 585.7 eV, corresponding to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2 respectively, both of which could be further deconvoluted into two peaks. The deconvoluted peaks at 585.7 and 575.5 eV were associated with Cr(III), while the peaks detected at 587.8 and 577.2 eV were corresponding to Cr(VI) [40,58]. The Cr species distribution (Fig. 6 c) demonstrates the pH and concentration-dependent nature of the Cr(VI). The various chemical species vary from CrO4 2− at pH higher than 6 to HCrO4 − and Cr2O7 2− at pH lower than 6 to H2CrO4 at pH less than 1. It is well known that when Cr2O7 2− ions are dissolved in water, they ionize to form CrO4 2− ions and H+ as stated by the given equations [59]:

When the solution pH is between 2 and 6, CrO4 2− forms an equilibrium with HCrO4 − (Eq. 12). Under acidic conditions, amine groups in PEI will remain positively charged. Therefore, as shown in Scheme 1 , it is hypothesized that the protonated amine groups in PEI are responsible for the removal of Cr(VI) from the aqueous solution through electrostatic attractions with the negatively charged Cr(VI) species. Meanwhile, Cr(VI) adsorption is usually accompanied by a reduction process (HCrO4 − has a high redox potential (1.33 eV) compared to CrO4 2− (−0.13), thereby highly reducible) [60]. Fig. 10 c shows the high-resolution spectrum of N 1 s. After adsorption, it can be seen that the peak shifted from 398.2 to 399.4 eV with a larger peak width (W) and a noticeable decrease in the intensity, indicating that the amine groups played a crucial role in the reduction process through the consumption of protons according to the following equations:

Another evidence is that the maximum peak of O 1s shifted from 531.4 to 530.8 eV (Fig. 10 d), speculating that Zn participated in the adsorption process through the hydroxylation of Cr(III) or Cr(VI) to form Zn-O-Cr [49,62].

The possibility of Cr(VI) removal by PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM was hypothesized based on the findings stated above, and there might be two key steps to this removal process. First, electrostatic attraction between protonated amine groups and negatively charged Cr species in the acidic solution. The second route is the reduction of the adsorbed Cr(VI) to Cr(III).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Regeneration cycles of adsorbent PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM
ce:section.ce:para:
From the perspective of economy, environmental viability and long-term feasibility, for an ideal adsorbent to be used in practical applications, it must have good recycling characteristics. Since Cr(VI) is typically found in its anionic state and on the basis of adsorption behavior from the pH studies and mechanism, NaOH was used for the regeneration of the PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM [52]. Fig. 11 shows the reusability of the PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM. As shown, the Cr(VI) adsorption capacity did not alter appreciably up to the fourth cycle with more than 90 % removal efficiency. After the tenth cycle, the decline was about 17%, which could be attributed to the decrease in the active sites, the reduction in the amount of amine groups, and the leaching of ZIF-8 nanoparticles (confirmed by SEM). In general, Cr(VI) adsorption capacity by PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 remained high after ten cycles. The SEM image of PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 after ten regeneration cycles of adsorption is shown in Fig. S5
. The adsorbent still demonstrated good nanofiber morphology with a few pores due to ZIF-8 leaching. In addition, Zn leaching was measured by ICP-OES to evaluate if secondary pollution would result from the usage of the adsorbent. The leaching amount of Zn was 0.2923 mg·L−1, which is far below the allowable industrial effluents limit (5 mg·L−1) according to Chinese regulation authorities (GB 25466–2010). The results of the current study demonstrate that PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 can withstand several adsorption/desorption cycles with relatively stable adsorption capacity under extreme acidic pH (pH = 3). Spent pickling acid, acid mine drainage, and tannery waste are all examples of low pH effluents that are extensively spiked with Cr(VI). Therefore, the electrospun PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NCM is proved to be an environmentally viable and long-term feasible adsorbent for Cr(VI) removal.

In this study, a unique superhydrophilic PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NFs adsorbent was fabricated through a facile electrospinning method and applied to adsorb Cr(VI) from water. The functionalized NFs adsorbent, termed as nanofibrous composite membrane (NCM), exhibited efficient and stable removal of Cr(VI) from water with a maximum monolayer adsorption capacity of 403.5 mg·g−1. The inclusion of PEI transformed the surface into a superhydrophilic surface due to the abundant hydrophilic amine groups. The introduction of ZIF-8 MOF up to 5 % in the PAN/PEI NFs had a crucial impact on the structure and performance of the fabricated NFs adsorbent. The incorporated ZIF-8 significantly improved the uniformity of the NCM and changed the surface to a raspberry-like shape. Additionally, the NCMs as adsorbents had the added benefit of being more convenient to handle during recycling. The surface adsorption, pore-filling mechanism, electrostatic interaction, and reduction were responsible for removing Cr(VI) from aqueous solution. Based on the findings, the electrospun PAN/PEI@ZIF-8 NFs adsorbent appears to be a potential option for Cr(VI) removal from wastewater.
